Mistakes All Programmers Make

Mar 17, 2017 - 12:00 -- Erik Hallmark

Programming is complicated, and programmers are bound to make mistakes, whether they've been programming for two weeks or five years. The more mistakes that a programmer knows they about, the more they can avoid.

Without any further introduction, here's some of the most common mistakes that all programmers will make at some point.

1. Not understanding the difference between reference and value types

This is probably the most common mistakes that new programmers make, and it's a serious problem. Half the new programmers I see seem to have no idea about these two different things, and they're pretty crucial concepts for programming.

While this is a pretty complex subject, and will definitely require more research if your not familiar with these concepts, but I'll do my best to explain them now.

Put simply, reference types are created in a special place in memory called the heap, the heap is somewhere off in memory away from where current functions are running, bits of your code then references them. Value types are created in the stack frame, along with the rest of your function.

In most programs, you can created reference and value types as classes and structs. Where a class is a reference type and a struct is a value type.

The biggest difference between these types is what happens when they're passed to a function as an argument. When you pass a reference type to a function what you're really passing is an address in memory that points to where that type is held, when you pass a value type you're copying the data out of that type and placing it into the functions stack frame. This means that if a functions makes a modifcation to a reference that is passed to it, the function that passed the code will also be able to see the changes that were made.

Another big difference between the two is the way that most languages handle conditional logic, when you compare two reference types to see if they are equal to one another, normally the reference addresses will be compared, not the actual data. Where when you compare value types you compare the actual data held in them.

If you want more info on how this works, check out this great explanation of how they work in C#
